bibl.title: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, July 21, 1942

div1.p: Taylor writes that he will not be able to meet with Hench. However, he feels that his knowledge of the yellow fever experiments would have been of interest to Hench and so offers his services in the future.

div1.head: Letter from John R. Taylor to Philip Showalter Hench, July 21, 1942
div1.opener:
548 Grand Ave
Upper Darby
Pennsylvania
July 21st 1942
Dr Phillip S. Hench.
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr Hench
div1.p:
I received the photographs which you
returned and everything is satisfactory.

While I am glad to know that your services
are to be available to the Army, I regret that the
indications are I will not have the pleasure of
meeting you. The amount of data which I possess on the various
experiments on the cause of yellow fever for
many years past, and my personal contact with
many of the workers, including Reed, Carroll,
Agramonte, Gorgas, Finlay, Guiteras and others
would have been of interest to you.

Congratulations to you on the award of the
Heberden Medal for 1942.

It has been a pleasure to know you, if
only by correspondence, and if I can be of
any service to you at any time, call on me.
